Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story:
My phone buzzes with a message from my mother: “Send me a photo of your outfit for the office party!” She always wants to see what I’m wearing, especially for big events. I know she expects me to look presentable and modern, like the other young women she admires on social media. At the same time, I feel the weight of my faith—my commitment to dress modestly, to cover my arms and hair, even when everyone else at work will be in sleeveless dresses and styled hair. 

I stare at my wardrobe, torn between the sleek dress my mother bought me last Eid and the long-sleeved abaya I usually wear. My mother’s texts keep coming, asking for updates, wanting to know if I’ll fit in with my colleagues. I want to make her proud, to show her I belong, but I also want to honor my beliefs. My heart pounds as I try to compose a reply, feeling the pressure from both sides, unsure how to satisfy both my mother’s wishes and my own sense of faith.
